_prev_prog_3.Description: Each of the two tanks used in the storage process are equipped with relief valve devices that have been calculated to be adequate for the size of storage tanks.  Product is refrigerated to maintain a liquid temperature between 32 and 39 degrees Fahrenheit to maintain purity and reduce the amount of polymerization.  The vessels were emptied in the summer of 2003 and certified API inspections were conducted.  A new flare system dedicated to the butadiene process was installed and commissioned in 2004.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
MAGELLAN MIDSTREAM PARTNERS, L.P.

Environmental Protection Agency - Risk Management Plan
Galena Park Terminal
RMP Executive Summary
2009 Resubmittal 


DESCRIPTION OF STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES

The Galena Park Terminal is a marine refined products terminal owned by Magellan Terminal Holdings, L.P.  The facility is located in Galena Park, TX and stores and distributes petroleum products such as gasoline and diesel occupying 196 acres with above ground storage tanks and two pressure vessels.  The pressure vessels accommodate the handling of 1,3-Butadiene to receive and deliver Butadiene by pipeline, tankcar, barge and ship.  The 1,3-Butadiene tanks are refrigerated for product quality reasons. This is the only regulated process governed by OSHA's Process Safety Management (PSM) regulation and the EPA's Risk Management Plan (RMP) regulation, meeting the NFPA 4 flammability requirements governing RMP.  The facility is required to comply with the PSM and RMP regulations because greater than 10,000 lbs of butadiene is stored onsite.  

The butadiene system includes two pressure vessels, chillers, exchangers, a flare, and associated piping.  The vessels and associated piping and equipment may contain over 17,706,277 lbs of butadiene.


ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

The Galena Park Terminal has a strong commitment to worker and public safety, along with resources invested in accident prevention, such as training personnel and contractors in design, installation, operations, and maintenance procedures.  If an emergency were to occur, it is the companyA?s policy to notify the Galena Park LEPC and request that they respond to the emergency.


WORST CASE SCENARIO DESCRIPTION

As discussed in the Risk Management Program Guidance for Offsite Consequence Analysis, the EPA has defined the Worst-Case Scenario (WCS) as the release of the largest quantity of a regulated substance from a single vessel or process line failure that resul

ts in the greatest distance to an endpoint.  At Galena Park, the regulated substance is butadiene which is a flammable substance.  This WCS assumes the entire quantity contained in the largest vessel or section of piping within the butadiene system releases to the atmosphere, forms a vapor cloud, and is subsequently detonated.  One (1) pound per square inch overpressure is used as the endpoint as this is the threshold for potentially serious injuries to people from flying glass, falling debris, and other explosion effects.  

At Galena Park the largest quantity of the covered flammable substance, butadiene, is the largest of the butadiene tanks, T-201-340.  The WCS assumes this vessel in its entirety is released catastrophically to the atmosphere and the vapor cloud formed is ignited and then at some distance from the center of the explosion reaches an endpoint of one (1) PSI overpressure.  A total of 8,834,640 lbs is the maximum amount of butadiene that is stored tank in T-201-340 tanking into account an administrative control limiting the maximum level of butadiene in the tank to 83 feet and 4 inches.  Using RMP*Comp to calculate the distance to endpoint, a 1.60 mile radius is estimated to be impacted if the worst case type of release occurred at Galena Park.  


ALTERNATIVE CASE SCENARIO DESPRICTION

The Galena Park Terminal's alternative release scenario is the total failure of a 10A? pipeline flange gasket within the butadiene system.  In this scenario, the failed gasket would be the source of a release of butadiene estimated to be 480,000 pounds within a 4 hour time frame.  Then calculated as a BLEVE condition using RMP*Comp; the radius of exposure for a 1 psi overpressure is 0.7 miles from the center of the release.  This scenario was used due to the fact that a flange gasket has a higher probability of failure than other pieces of equipment, although a total failure is highly unlikely due to the maintenance and operational procedures and checks that are in p

lace.


GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND MAINTENANCE PROGRAM

The regulated butadiene system within the facility is compliant with the thirteen (13) elements of Process Safety Management and other employee training programs, along with operating and maintenance procedures.  The process controls listed in Section 7.4e were chosen based on whether or not they were used as safeguards in the last PHA for this facility or if they were recommended from the latest PHA and installed prior to the RMP submittal.  There may be other process controls in this facility that were not identified as safeguards in the last PHA.  The facility has no "Trade Secrets".  The facility complies with the Federal and State requirements for leak detection of valves, pumps, and flanges.  Inspections are conducted and documented to ensure the integrity of the regulated equipment.


FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

There has been no accidental release from the butadiene process at the Galena Park terminal.


EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

The facility maintains a written Emergency Response Plan.  In the event of fire or explosion, or a release of a regulated substance from the butane process, entry within the distance to the specified endpoint may pose a danger to public emergency responders.  Therefore, emergency responders should not enter the area unless directed through the unified or incident command process.  The undersigned certifies that to the best of my knowledge, information, and belief, the information submitted is true, accurate, and complete.


PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

No changes are currently planned to the butadiene process.  As opportunities for improvement associated with the new butane process arise at the Galena Park Terminal, they will be evaluated by Magellan Terminal Holdings, L.P.
